posts.title: Welcome!
posts.content: Welcome to ThinkFeed! This app is designed to help you learn as you scroll: instead of wasting your time, you can learn something new. From the Settings page, you can pick the categories you are interested in learning.

posts.title: Welcome!
posts.content: You can 'like' posts you enjoy, track your success at quizzes, and [soon] add your own comments. You can [soon] even share a fact you really like with your friends. Keep looking for updates, as the knowledge base will continue to grow. There are pictures, too!

posts.title: Your Cells Use Molecular Motors 🏃
posts.content: Tiny protein motors like kinesin 'walk' along microtubules carrying cargo inside your cells.

posts.title: Mitochondria Have Their Own DNA 🔋
posts.content: Mitochondria were once free-living bacteria and still carry their own DNA. They’re inherited from your mother!

posts.title: CRISPR Edits Genes ✂️
posts.content: CRISPR is a revolutionary tool that lets scientists cut and rewrite DNA with precision.

posts.title: There’s More Bacteria Than You 🦠
posts.content: Bacterial cells in and on your body outnumber your human cells. Most are harmless or even helpful!

posts.title: You Started As One Cell 👶
posts.content: You began as a single fertilized egg that divided and specialized into trillions of cells.

posts.title: Some Animals Can Regrow Organs 🦎
posts.content: Axolotls and some lizards can regenerate limbs, tails, and even parts of their hearts or brains.

posts.title: Proteins Fold Like Origami 🧬
posts.content: A protein’s function depends on its 3D shape, which folds spontaneously based on its amino acid sequence.

posts.title: Photosynthesis Powers Life 🌿
posts.content: Plants convert sunlight, water, and CO₂ into oxygen and sugar. Without it, there’d be no food or air!

posts.title: Your Genome Has 'Junk' DNA 🧩
posts.content: Over 98% of your DNA doesn’t code for proteins. Some of it regulates genes, but a lot is still mysterious.

posts.title: You Replace Your Skin Every Month 🧖
posts.content: Your body sheds around 30,000 skin cells every minute and replaces your entire outer layer monthly.

posts.title: Cell Communication = Chemical Texting 📱
posts.content: Cells talk to each other using chemical signals like hormones and neurotransmitters.

posts.title: Embryos Have Gills and Tails 🐣
posts.content: Human embryos briefly develop structures like tails and pharyngeal arches — a reminder of our evolutionary past.

posts.title: Blood Types Are Sugary Flags 🩸
posts.content: Your blood type depends on sugar molecules on your red blood cells. That’s why mixing types can be dangerous.

posts.title: DNA is 2 Meters Long! 🧵
posts.content: Each of your cells contains about 2 meters of DNA coiled into the nucleus. That’s 200 billion km in your whole body!

posts.title: RNA Viruses Mutate Fast 🧬
posts.content: Viruses like flu and COVID mutate rapidly because RNA polymerases lack error correction.

posts.title: Neurons Don’t Touch ✨
posts.content: Neurons communicate across tiny gaps called synapses, using chemicals to pass signals between them.

posts.title: Telomeres Count Your Cell's Age ⏳
posts.content: Telomeres are caps on chromosomes that get shorter with each cell division. When they run out, the cell dies or stops dividing.

posts.title: Gene Expression is Like a Dimmer Switch 🎚️
posts.content: Genes aren’t just on or off — cells can control how strongly a gene is expressed based on needs.

posts.title: Viruses Aren’t Really Alive 🦠
posts.content: Viruses don’t eat, breathe, or reproduce on their own. They hijack your cells to do the work!

posts.title: Evolution Never Stops 🔁
posts.content: Even today, species — including humans — are constantly adapting and changing in response to their environment.

posts.title: Everything’s Made of Quarks 🧱
posts.content: Protons and neutrons are made of even smaller particles called quarks. They're held together by the strong force!

posts.title: Electron Orbitals Aren’t Orbits ⚛️
posts.content: Electrons don't orbit like planets — they exist in 'clouds' of probability called orbitals.

posts.title: Water is Weird 💧
posts.content: Water expands when it freezes — unlike most substances — and that's why ice floats.

posts.title: Acids and Bases Have Opposite Powers ⚖️
posts.content: Acids donate protons (H⁺), bases accept them. The pH scale measures this balance.

posts.title: Mole Isn’t an Animal 🐹
posts.content: A mole is 6.022 × 10²³ of something — it’s how chemists count atoms and molecules.

posts.title: Enzymes Speed Things Up 🔬
posts.content: Catalysts like enzymes lower activation energy, making reactions happen faster — without being used up.

posts.title: Radioactive Decay is Predictable 📉
posts.content: Unstable atoms decay over time with a constant half-life. That’s how we date ancient fossils!

posts.title: Bond Types = Chemical Behavior 🧪
posts.content: Covalent, ionic, and metallic bonds all behave differently. They determine everything from melting point to conductivity.

posts.title: Allotropes Are Same Element, Different Form 🌑💎
posts.content: Graphite and diamond are both carbon, but arranged differently. That’s why one is soft and the other super hard!

posts.title: Avogadro Was Right 📦
posts.content: Equal volumes of gases, at the same temperature and pressure, contain the same number of molecules.

posts.title: Electronegativity Predicts Reactivity ⚡
posts.content: The more electronegative an element, the more it pulls electrons in a bond. Fluorine is the king of this!

posts.title: Periodic Table Predicts the Future 🔮
posts.content: The periodic table’s layout shows trends in reactivity, size, and properties — it's like a cheat sheet for chemists.

posts.title: pH = Power of Hydrogen 🔍
posts.content: A pH of 7 is neutral. Lower is acidic, higher is basic — and every number is 10× stronger than the next!

posts.title: Organic Chemistry = Carbon Chains 🧬
posts.content: Organic chemistry studies carbon-based compounds — the basis of life and most pharmaceuticals.

posts.title: Electrons Jump Energy Levels 🎢
posts.content: Electrons absorb or release energy to jump between energy levels. That’s how neon signs glow!

posts.title: Oxidation Isn’t Just Rust 🔩
posts.content: Oxidation is when atoms lose electrons — it happens in fire, batteries, and metabolism.

posts.title: Polymers Are Long Chain Molecules 🧵
posts.content: Plastics are made of repeating units called polymers — some natural, some man-made.

posts.title: Entropy Measures Disorder 🔄
posts.content: Entropy is a measure of chaos in a system — and it always increases over time.

posts.title: Superacids Melt Almost Anything 💥
posts.content: Some acids are millions of times stronger than sulfuric acid. They can dissolve even hydrocarbons!

posts.title: Chemiluminescence = Glow Chemistry ✨
posts.content: Some chemical reactions produce light without heat — that’s how glow sticks work!

posts.title: Relativity of Simultaneity 🕰️
posts.content: Two events that happen at the same time in one frame of reference may not be simultaneous in another. Welcome to Einstein’s world!

posts.title: Time Dilation is Real ⏳
posts.content: Astronauts on the ISS age a tiny bit slower than people on Earth due to time dilation. Gravity and motion mess with time!

posts.title: Photons Have No Mass — But Momentum! ⚡
posts.content: Photons are massless, but they still carry momentum. That’s how solar sails work!

posts.title: Quantum Tunneling: Ghost Particles 🚪
posts.content: In quantum mechanics, particles can 'tunnel' through barriers they shouldn’t be able to cross. It’s like walking through walls — statistically!

posts.title: Heisenberg Was Sure About Uncertainty 🤯
posts.content: You can’t precisely know both a particle’s position and momentum. The more you know one, the less you know the other.

posts.title: The Universe Has No Center 🌌
posts.content: Every point in the expanding universe sees everything else moving away. There’s no 'center' — it’s expanding everywhere!

posts.title: You’re Mostly Empty Space 💨
posts.content: If atoms were the size of stadiums, their nuclei would be tiny marbles in the center. Most of you is void!

posts.title: Antimatter Exists — Just Rarely 🧿
posts.content: Every particle has an opposite called an antiparticle. If they meet, they annihilate!

posts.title: The Double-Slit Mystery 🎯
posts.content: Particles act like waves and can interfere with themselves. Until you watch — then they behave like particles!

posts.title: Absolute Zero = No Motion? Not Quite ❄️
posts.content: At absolute zero, atoms reach their lowest energy — but thanks to quantum mechanics, they never completely stop moving.

posts.title: Black Holes Aren’t Holes 🕳️
posts.content: They’re extremely dense objects with gravity so strong, not even light escapes. They're not portals — they’re prisons!

posts.title: Gravity = Geometry 📐
posts.content: Einstein showed that gravity is really the bending of spacetime by mass. Matter tells space how to curve, and space tells matter how to move.

posts.title: Muon Magic: Detecting the Impossible 🧪
posts.content: Muons are like heavy electrons and constantly shower Earth from space. Without relativity, they’d decay before reaching the ground.

posts.title: Schrödinger's Cat Is Both Alive and Dead 🐱
posts.content: In quantum theory, particles exist in multiple states until measured. So does the cat — until you open the box.

posts.title: Neutrinos Pass Right Through You 🚶
posts.content: Trillions of neutrinos zoom through your body every second. They barely interact with matter at all!

posts.title: Planck Time: The Smallest Unit of Time ⌛
posts.content: Planck time is the shortest meaningful time interval — about 10^-43 seconds. It’s the speed limit of time!

posts.title: Lasers Are Organized Light 🔦
posts.content: Lasers produce light waves that are all in sync. That’s why they’re so powerful and precise!

posts.title: Thermodynamics Never Lies ♨️
posts.content: The laws of thermodynamics govern energy, entropy, and heat. You can’t win, you can’t break even, and you can’t get out of the game.

posts.title: Spacetime Isn’t Just a Metaphor 🧠
posts.content: Time and space are connected as one fabric — spacetime. Mess with one, and the other changes too.

posts.title: Faster Than Light? Maybe… 📡
posts.content: Some particles like tachyons are hypothetical and would travel faster than light — but no real evidence exists (yet).

posts.title: Infinity ♾️
posts.content: There are different sizes of infinity! Some infinities are bigger than others — seriously.

posts.title: Speed of Light
posts.content: Light travels at about 299,792 kilometers per second — fast enough to circle Earth 7.5 times in one second!

posts.title: Table Salt
posts.content: The salt on your fries is made from two deadly elements: sodium (explosive) and chlorine (toxic gas). Together? Harmless!

posts.title: Octopus Hearts ❤️❤️❤️
posts.content: An octopus has *three* hearts — and two of them stop beating when it swims.

posts.title: Brain Power
posts.content: Your brain uses about 20% of your body’s energy — more than any other organ!

posts.title: Napoleon Wasn’t Short
posts.content: He was actually average height for his time — about 5'6"!

posts.title: Bananas Are Berries 🍌
posts.content: According to botany, bananas are berries — but strawberries aren’t!

posts.title: First Computer Bug 🐛
posts.content: The first actual computer 'bug' was a real moth stuck in a relay in 1947.

posts.title: Shakespeare Invented Words
posts.content: William Shakespeare invented over 1,700 words we still use today, like 'bedroom' and 'swagger'.

posts.title: Van Gogh Sold One Painting
posts.content: In his lifetime, Vincent van Gogh only sold one painting — now they sell for millions.

posts.title: Wants vs. Needs
posts.content: Economics is all about choices: what you *want* versus what you really *need*.

posts.title: Pi Never Ends 🥧
posts.content: The number π (pi) goes on forever without repeating. Computers have calculated trillions of digits!

posts.title: You Glow in the Dark
posts.content: Your body emits tiny amounts of light — it's just too weak for our eyes to see.

posts.title: Sound in Space?
posts.content: In space, no one can hear you scream — because sound needs a medium like air to travel.

posts.title: T-Rex Time
posts.content: Tyrannosaurus rex lived closer in time to you than to the Stegosaurus!

posts.title: Coding is Language
posts.content: Learning to code is like learning a new language — but your computer is the one listening.

posts.title: French Is Everywhere
posts.content: French is an official language in 29 countries — from France to Canada to parts of Africa!

posts.title: Why Is Art So Expensive?
posts.content: Art prices aren’t always about talent — it’s often about fame, rarity, and hype.

posts.title: Water’s Weird
posts.content: Water expands when it freezes — that's why ice floats!

posts.title: Supply and Demand
posts.content: When things are rare and people want them? Prices go up. That's supply and demand!

posts.title: Bananas Are Berries 🍌
posts.content: According to botany, bananas are berries — but strawberries aren’t!

posts.title: Photosynthesis 🌿
posts.content: Photosynthesis is how plants convert sunlight, water, and CO₂ into oxygen and glucose.

posts.title: Did You Know? Space Facts
posts.content: A day on Venus is longer than its year! Venus takes 243 Earth days to rotate on its axis but only 225 Earth days to orbit the Sun.

posts.title: Brain Health Quiz
posts.content: Which food is known to boost brain function?|Candy|Pizza|Blueberries|Blueberries

posts.title: Ocean Facts
posts.content: The blue whale's heart is so big that a human could swim through its arteries! These magnificent creatures are the largest animals ever known to exist.

posts.title: Tech History Quiz
posts.content: Who is known as the first computer programmer?|Bill Gates|Ada Lovelace|Steve Jobs|Ada Lovelace

posts.title: Mindfulness Meditation
posts.content: Taking just 10 minutes a day for meditation can significantly reduce stress and improve focus. Start with simple breathing exercises.

posts.title: Amazing Architecture
posts.content: The Sagrada Familia in Barcelona has been under construction since 1882! It's expected to be completed in 2026.

posts.title: Coding Challenge
posts.content: What does HTML stand for?|High Tech Markup Language|Hyper Text Markup Language|Hybrid Text Making Language|Hyper Text Markup Language

posts.title: Startup Success
posts.content: 90% of startups fail, but understanding why can help you succeed. Focus on market needs and sustainable growth.

posts.title: Language Learning Tip
posts.content: Learning a new language? Try thinking directly in that language instead of translating from your native tongue.

posts.title: AI Ethics
posts.content: As AI becomes more prevalent, ethical considerations in its development and deployment are crucial for society.

posts.title: Geography Quiz
posts.content: Which is the largest desert in the world?|Sahara|Arabian|Antarctic|Antarctic

posts.title: Innovation History
posts.content: The first computer mouse was made of wood! Douglas Engelbart invented it in the 1960s.

posts.title: Financial Wisdom
posts.content: The rule of 72: Divide 72 by your investment's interest rate to estimate how many years it will take for your money to double.

posts.title: Art History Quiz
posts.content: Who painted 'The Starry Night'?|Leonardo da Vinci|Claude Monet|Vincent van Gogh|Vincent van Gogh

posts.title: Quiz time!
posts.content: Which planet is known as the Red Planet?|Venus|Mars|Jupiter|Mars

posts.content: What is the square root of 64?|6|8|10|8

posts.content: What gas do plants absorb?|Oxygen|Carbon Dioxide|Nitrogen|Carbon Dioxide

posts.content: What planet is known as the Red Planet?|Mars|Jupiter|Venus|Mars

posts.content: What is a budget?|Spending plan|Investment return|Loan agreement|Spending plan

posts.title: LISP Fact
posts.content: LISP was created by John McCarthy in 1958.

posts.title: LISP Fact
posts.content: LISP stands for 'LISt Processing'.

posts.title: LISP Fact
posts.content: LISP was one of the first programming languages to support recursion.

posts.title: LISP Fact
posts.content: Code and data in LISP share the same structure: the list.

posts.title: LISP Fact
posts.content: LISP uses prefix notation, also known as Polish notation.

posts.title: LISP Fact
posts.content: LISP introduced the concept of garbage collection.

posts.title: LISP Fact
posts.content: Common Lisp and Scheme are two of the most widely used LISP dialects.

posts.title: LISP Fact
posts.content: LISP functions are first-class objects.

posts.title: LISP Fact
posts.content: The 'car' and 'cdr' functions access the head and tail of a list, respectively.

posts.title: LISP Fact
posts.content: LISP macros allow programmers to extend the language.

posts.title: Quiz: Who created the LISP programming language?
posts.content: Who created the LISP programming language?|Dennis Ritchie|John McCarthy|Alan Turing|John McCarthy

posts.title: Quiz: What does LISP stand for?
posts.content: What does LISP stand for?|Linear Programming|List Processing|Logical Syntax Parsing|List Processing

posts.title: Quiz: Which of the following is a common LISP dialect?
posts.content: Which of the following is a common LISP dialect?|Python|Haskell|Common Lisp|Common Lisp

posts.title: Quiz: Which notation does LISP use for expressions?
posts.content: Which notation does LISP use for expressions?|Infix|Postfix|Prefix|Prefix

posts.title: Quiz: What do 'car' and 'cdr' functions operate on in LISP?
posts.content: What do 'car' and 'cdr' functions operate on in LISP?|Strings|Lists|Numbers|Lists

posts.title: Prime Numbers
posts.content: A prime number is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself.

posts.title: Pi
posts.content: Pi is an irrational number approximately equal to 3.14159, representing the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter.

posts.title: Golden Ratio
posts.content: The golden ratio is approximately 1.618 and appears frequently in geometry, art, and nature.

posts.title: Quadratic Formula
posts.content: The quadratic formula solves ax²+bx+c=0 and is x = (-b ± √(b²-4ac))/(2a).

posts.title: Fibonacci Sequence
posts.content: The Fibonacci sequence is a series where each number is the sum of the two preceding ones.

posts.title: Zero
posts.content: Zero is the only real number that is neither positive nor negative.

posts.title: Imaginary Numbers
posts.content: The square root of -1 is denoted as i, the basis for imaginary numbers.

posts.title: Area of a Circle
posts.content: The area of a circle is πr², where r is the radius.

posts.title: Probability
posts.content: Probability is a measure of the likelihood that an event will occur, ranging from 0 to 1.

posts.title: Logarithms
posts.content: A logarithm is the inverse operation to exponentiation.

posts.title: Photosynthesis
posts.content: Photosynthesis is how plants convert sunlight, water, and CO₂ into oxygen and glucose.

posts.title: DNA Structure
posts.content: DNA is composed of two strands forming a double helix.

posts.title: Newton’s Laws
posts.content: Newton’s three laws explain motion and force.

posts.title: Periodic Table
posts.content: The periodic table organizes elements by increasing atomic number.

posts.title: Atoms
posts.content: Atoms are the basic units of matter, made of protons, neutrons, and electrons.

posts.title: Gravity
posts.content: Gravity is a force that attracts two bodies toward each other.

posts.title: Evaporation
posts.content: Evaporation is the process of a liquid turning into vapor.

posts.title: Light Speed
posts.content: The speed of light in vacuum is approximately 299,792 kilometers per second.

posts.title: Electricity
posts.content: Electricity is the flow of electric charge, primarily carried by electrons.

posts.title: Mitosis
posts.content: Mitosis is a process where a single cell divides into two identical daughter cells.

posts.title: WWII
posts.content: World War II lasted from 1939 to 1945, involving major world powers.

posts.title: Industrial Revolution
posts.content: The Industrial Revolution began in the 18th century and drastically changed manufacturing.

posts.title: French Revolution
posts.content: The French Revolution (1789–1799) overthrew the monarchy and led to social change.

posts.title: Printing Press
posts.content: Invented by Gutenberg in the 15th century, it revolutionized information dissemination.

posts.title: Roman Empire
posts.content: The Roman Empire dominated much of Europe and the Mediterranean for centuries.

posts.title: Great Depression
posts.content: The Great Depression was a worldwide economic downturn in the 1930s.

posts.title: Cold War
posts.content: The Cold War was a geopolitical tension between the US and USSR after WWII.

posts.title: American Revolution
posts.content: The American Revolution led to the United States gaining independence in 1776.

posts.title: Ancient Egypt
posts.content: Ancient Egyptians built pyramids and developed one of the earliest writing systems.

posts.title: Moon Landing
posts.content: Apollo 11 landed the first humans on the Moon in 1969.

posts.title: Corporate Finance
posts.content: Corporate finance deals with funding sources, capital structuring, and investment decisions.

posts.title: Market Economy
posts.content: A market economy relies on supply and demand to allocate resources and set prices.

posts.title: Entrepreneurship
posts.content: Entrepreneurship is the process of starting and running a new business to make a profit.

posts.title: Supply Chain Management
posts.content: Supply chain management involves overseeing the flow of goods and services from origin to consumer.

posts.title: Business Ethics
posts.content: Business ethics are principles that guide the conduct of a business's actions and decisions.

posts.title: Investment Analysis
posts.content: Investment analysis evaluates the potential of an investment to generate returns.

posts.title: Consumer Behavior
posts.content: Consumer behavior studies how individuals make decisions to spend their resources.

posts.title: Financial Statements
posts.content: Financial statements summarize the financial performance and position of a business.

posts.title: Risk Management
posts.content: Risk management identifies, assesses, and prioritizes risks to minimize their impact.

posts.title: Marketing Strategies
posts.content: Marketing strategies are plans to reach and persuade target audiences to buy products.

posts.title: Renaissance Art
posts.content: The Renaissance was a period of renewed interest in art and culture in Europe.

posts.title: Impressionism
posts.content: Impressionism is an art movement characterized by small, visible brush strokes and open composition.

posts.title: Sculpture Techniques
posts.content: Sculpture techniques include carving, modeling, casting, and assembling materials.

posts.title: Abstract Art
posts.content: Abstract art uses shapes, colors, and forms to create compositions independent of visual references.

posts.title: Street Art
posts.content: Street art is visual art created in public locations, often addressing social issues.

posts.title: Photography
posts.content: Photography captures images using light-sensitive surfaces, creating a visual representation of reality.

posts.title: Theater Origins
posts.content: Theater originated in ancient Greece as a form of storytelling and performance.

posts.title: Music Genres
posts.content: Music genres categorize music based on similarities in form, style, or subject matter.

posts.title: Dance Forms
posts.content: Dance forms vary widely, including ballet, hip-hop, and traditional folk dances.

posts.title: Literary Movements
posts.content: Literary movements are trends in literature reflecting specific themes, styles, or philosophies.

posts.title: Algorithms
posts.content: An algorithm is a step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or completing a task.

posts.title: Data Structures
posts.content: Data structures organize and store data efficiently for optimal access and modification.

posts.title: Machine Learning
posts.content: Machine learning enables computers to learn from data and improve their performance over time.

posts.title: Programming Languages
posts.content: Programming languages are formal languages used to communicate instructions to a computer.

posts.title: Cybersecurity
posts.content: Cybersecurity protects computer systems from theft, damage, or unauthorized access.

posts.title: Web Development
posts.content: Web development involves building and maintaining websites and web applications.

posts.title: Artificial Intelligence
posts.content: Artificial intelligence simulates human intelligence in machines to perform tasks autonomously.

posts.title: Cloud Computing
posts.content: Cloud computing delivers computing services over the internet, enabling on-demand access to resources.

posts.title: Software Engineering
posts.content: Software engineering applies engineering principles to software development and maintenance.

posts.title: Database Management
posts.content: Database management involves storing, retrieving, and managing data in databases.

posts.title: Language Families
posts.content: Language families group languages based on common ancestry and shared characteristics.

posts.title: Grammar Rules
posts.content: Grammar rules govern the structure and composition of sentences in a language.

posts.title: Dialects
posts.content: Dialects are regional variations of a language, differing in pronunciation, vocabulary, and grammar.

posts.title: Translation
posts.content: Translation is the process of converting text from one language to another while preserving meaning.

posts.title: Language Acquisition
posts.content: Language acquisition is the process by which people learn their native language.

posts.title: Phonetics
posts.content: Phonetics studies the sounds of human speech and their production, transmission, and perception.

posts.title: Linguistics
posts.content: Linguistics is the scientific study of language and its structure.

posts.title: Language Preservation
posts.content: Language preservation aims to protect and maintain endangered languages from extinction.

posts.title: Bilingualism
posts.content: Bilingualism is the ability to speak and understand two languages fluently.

posts.title: Language and Culture
posts.content: Language and culture are interconnected, influencing each other in communication and expression.

posts.title: Supply and Demand
posts.content: Supply and demand are fundamental concepts in economics that determine prices in a market.

posts.title: Inflation
posts.content: Inflation is the rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services rises.

posts.title: Gross Domestic Product
posts.content: Gross Domestic Product (GDP) measures the economic performance of a country.

posts.title: Monetary Policy
posts.content: Monetary policy involves managing the money supply and interest rates to influence the economy.

posts.title: Fiscal Policy
posts.content: Fiscal policy uses government spending and taxation to influence the economy's performance.

posts.title: Trade Balance
posts.content: The trade balance measures the difference between a country's exports and imports.

posts.title: Labor Market
posts.content: The labor market is the supply and demand for labor, where employers seek employees.

posts.title: Consumer Price Index
posts.content: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) measures the average change in prices paid by consumers over time.

posts.title: Economic Growth
posts.content: Economic growth refers to an increase in the production of goods and services over time.

posts.title: Market Structures
posts.content: Market structures describe the organizational characteristics of a market, influencing competition.

posts.title: Divisibility Rule for 3
posts.content: A number is divisible by 3 if the sum of its digits is divisible by 3.

posts.title: Gravity on the Moon
posts.content: The Moon's gravity is about 1/6th as strong as Earth's.

posts.title: The Silk Road
posts.content: The Silk Road was a trade network connecting Asia and Europe for centuries.

posts.title: Net Profit
posts.content: Net profit is revenue minus all expenses, taxes, and costs.

posts.title: Surrealism
posts.content: Surrealism is an art movement that emphasizes the irrational and dream-like.

posts.title: Boolean Logic
posts.content: Boolean logic uses true and false values to perform logical operations in programming.

posts.title: Infinitive Verbs
posts.content: In English, infinitives are the base form of a verb, often preceded by 'to'.

posts.title: Opportunity Cost
posts.content: Opportunity cost is the value of the best alternative not chosen.

posts.title: Even Numbers
posts.content: Even numbers are integers divisible by 2, like -4, 0, and 12.

posts.title: States of Matter
posts.content: The four basic states of matter are solid, liquid, gas, and plasma.

posts.title: Treaty of Versailles
posts.content: The Treaty of Versailles formally ended World War I in 1919.

posts.title: Break-even Point
posts.content: The break-even point is when total revenue equals total costs.
